poem:
The Gourd's New Story  

From fields of labor, lined with sweat,  
A dream sprouted—unforseen,  
Not furrows, but carved tales and light,  
Gourds, cradles of surprise,  
Turn hands of toil to art divine.  
In Mississippi's silent gaze,  
Old plows rest; hard shells open,  
Life swells once more, unexpectedly ripe.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "A new start after 60: I wanted to retire from farming – but never dreamed I would become an artist It was while touring Mississippi in an old RV that John Ingall and his wife, Jane, first spotted the plant that would change their lives: the hardshell gourd, a plump, squash-like fruit with a thick, woody skin. After that, they saw them almost everywhere they went: carved gourds in porches, hanging gourds, gourds reimagined as". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
